Also because it's dangerous to them. If the bitten predator reels back too fast it could toss them around and/or damage their teeth/fangs. Also, the predator could just get pissed at it and attack back.
So not only is it a waste of venom, it's also a huge risk to the snake.
In fact, some snakes, the Western Hognose being a prominent example, will bluff-strike (pretend to strike, but their mouths are actually closed) alongside tons of hissing and head-raising to scare off predator without paining them (this avoiding the danger of pain reflexes like reeling back) and without risking the safety of their hind fangs.

For the record, not all snakes in the family Colubridae are "rear-fanged". Most are actually non-venomous. Some infamous examples of venomous rear-fanged colubrids are the Boomslang and Twigsnakes of Africa, and Hog-nosed Snakes of North America.  Gartersnakes in the genus Thamnophis are actually venomous as well. Remember,  venom doesn't necessarily mean dangerous to humans. Many rear-fanged snakes have venom that evolved to secure specific prey items such as amphibians and even other snakes. This venom is medically insignificant to humans. Others, such as the boomslang and twigsnake, have extremely dangerous venom.
